speaker: SKINNER
line: This is it? I just sign this and it's done?

speaker: JANE CASSAL
line: As soon as I file it with the City Clerk.

speaker: SKINNER
line: This pen... she gave it to me. It was an anniversary present. I don't remember which one.

speaker: JANE CASSAL
line: Walter. They are expecting the signed documents by the end of business today - which was 10 minutes ago.

speaker: SKINNER
line: I know what time it is.

speaker: JANE CASSAL
line: Then you should sign.

speaker: JANE CASSAL
line: What are you doing, Walter?

speaker: SKINNER
line: After seventeen years, they can wait another day.

speaker: JANE CASSAL
line: Listen. No one knows better than I what an emotional experience this is...

speaker: SKINNER
line: Don't "lawyer" me, Jane. I'll do it tomorrow.

speaker: JANE CASSAL
line: Why put yourself through another day of this?

speaker: SKINNER
line: I said tomorrow.

speaker: CARINA SAYLES
line: Excuse me. Are you holding this for someone? It's the only open seat.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Go ahead.

speaker: BARTENDER
line: Good evening. What can I get you?

speaker: CARINA SAYLES
line: Tonic water with lime, please.

speaker: BARTENDER
line: Sir, would you like another one?

speaker: SKINNER
line: Sure.

speaker: CARINA SAYLES
line: Thanks.

speaker: SKINNER
line: For what? Ordering another drink?

speaker: CARINA SAYLES
line: There's a man behind me wearing a red tie. For some reason, he felt compelled to tell me half his life story. I was afraid if you got up, he might try to get in the other half.

speaker: SKINNER
line: I guess some people think that you owe something, just 'cause you're out alone.

speaker: CARINA SAYLES
line: Does it ever bother you?

speaker: SKINNER
line: What?

speaker: CARINA SAYLES
line: Being alone.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm looking for Detective Waltos?

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: Who's asking?

speaker: MULDER
line: My name is Mulder. I work with Assistant Director Skinner. I'd like to speak with him.

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: You can see him after he gives his statement. We're gonna finish up at the station house.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why don't you just get a statement here?

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: It seems that the Assistant Director is suffering from a minor memory lapse.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, it's me. I just got your message. You said Skinner called in a homicide?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, it appears to be a little more complicated than that. It seems like he had a front-row seat.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't understand.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't understand it either. They're not letting me talk to him. Hold on a second.

speaker: MULDER
line: Excuse me, sir?

speaker: SKINNER
line: I appreciate your concern, Agent Mulder, but there's no need for you to get involved in this.

speaker: MULDER
line: Detective? Detective? Detective? Can you at least tell me what happened? What does he say happened?

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: Well, he claims he met the victim in the bar downstairs. After a couple of drinks, they decided to get a room together, which is all fine except when he wakes up, he finds her lying next to him with a broken neck. That's all he says he remembers.

speaker: MULDER
line: You don't believe him?

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: He refused to take a polygraph test. It's not helping his credibility.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about the victim? Has she been identified?

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: Not yet. She had no purse, nothing with a name on it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, there must be evidence of an intruder of some kind.

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: Uh, Agent Mulder, I've been on the job for eighteen years. I know the drill.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, then, if you know the drill, then you should be canvassing hotel employees, housekeeping...

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: I appreciate that he's a colleague of yours, but I want you to understand something. He's also a suspect.

speaker: MULDER
line: Detective? When you're done questioning him, I'd appreciate a call.

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: All right.

speaker: MULDER
line: Get any of that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Most of it. Mulder, I'm on my way.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, no, I want you to take a look at that body. Get down to the coroner's. I'll meet you there.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The conspicuous absence of any contusions or lacerations would strongly suggest that the victim's injuries were sustained without a struggle. From my observations, I would have to concur with the county coroner's report that her murder was most probably a sudden and violent act in a vulnerable moment. Beyond this, I found nothing in my post-mortem examination to recommend further investigation.

speaker: MULDER
line: Beyond what?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Her spinal cord was crushed, Mulder. The cervical vertebrae was fractured in what appears to be manual trauma.

speaker: MULDER
line: Were Skinner's the only prints lifted from the body?

speaker: SCULLY
line: So far. They found no semen samples. There was some irritation, probably an allergic reaction to latex.

speaker: MULDER
line: At least they were having safe sex.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Have they learned anything more?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. Her name was Carina Sayles. She was a legal secretary for one of the criminal defense firms here in town.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Have you talked to anybody she worked with?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, I just got off the phone with one of the partners. She was fired a few weeks ago over an indiscretion.

speaker: SCULLY
line: An indiscretion?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, she was doing some moonlighting. She was taking a little work on the side for one of the firm's clients.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What kind of work?

speaker: MULDER
line: This client operated an escort service. She was a prostitute.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Give me five minutes here.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'll get the car.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Addendum: observed what appears to be a residual phosphorescence around the victim's mouth and nose. Note to have this analyzed.

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: Yes?

speaker: MULDER
line: Lorraine Kelleher?

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: She's busy right now. Is there something I can help you with?

speaker: MULDER
line: Busy or not, we need to speak with her.

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: I'll tell her you're here. Lorraine?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Business must be booming.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think you mean "banging."

speaker: LORRAINE KELLEHER
line: Whatever this is about, can we do it later? I'm running late for an appointment.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We'd like to ask you some questions about an employee of yours - Carina Sayles. She does work for you, doesn't she?

speaker: LORRAINE KELLEHER
line: I'm ten minutes late for a meeting with her.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, that's all right. I don't think she's gonna be making that meeting.

speaker: LORRAINE KELLEHER
line: Oh? Why not?

speaker: MULDER
line: She's dead. She was murdered last night.

speaker: LORRAINE KELLEHER
line: How?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's what we're still trying to determine.

speaker: LORRAINE KELLEHER
line: I, um, I don't know what to say.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, you can start by telling us if she was working last night, and if she was, who paid for her company.

speaker: LORRAINE KELLEHER
line: I'm afraid I can't do that.

speaker: MULDER
line: I guess that would hurt future book sales, huh?

speaker: LORRAINE KELLEHER
line: You'd be surprised who some of my clients are.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, I don't think I would be.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I also doubt that they'd want to get entangled in a homicide investigation.

speaker: MULDER
line: Look, we just need one name from you. Who hired Carina Sayles?

speaker: LORRAINE KELLEHER
line: Let's just say you both work for the government. And so do I.

speaker: MULDER
line: Cut the crap. Who hired her?

speaker: LORRAINE KELLEHER
line: She called me last night. She said that she'd met someone in a bar who was interested in a transaction. I took his credit card.

speaker: MULDER
line: Then you have his name.

speaker: LORRAINE KELLEHER
line: Walter Skinner.

speaker: MULDER
line: Thank you.

speaker: MULDER
line: What the hell was he thinking?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It just doesn't seem like him.

speaker: MULDER
line: You'd think he'd be a little more discrete.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I think the lack of discretion is the least of his sins.

speaker: MULDER
line: Still, not enough to prove anything conclusively.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, but that doesn't mean that we can discount the evidence.

speaker: MULDER
line: You really believe Skinner did this?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Look, Mulder, I feel the same way about Skinner as you do, but we were just shown a dated record with Skinner's credit card number on it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Credit card fraud happens every day.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Skinner was in bed with a prostitute at the time of her death, and he's offered us no explanation or alibi. Truth is, we don't know very much about him. We don't know what he does off duty, who he really is.

speaker: MULDER
line: We know that he's put his ass on the line for us a number of times. We owe it to him to find out what really happened.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Even if it means proving his guilt?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, Mulder. Thank you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who was that?

speaker: MULDER
line: Detective Waltos. Skinner's been released on his own recognizance.

speaker: MULDER
line: Sir? Sir?

speaker: SKINNER
line: This doesn't concern either of you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Of course it concerns us.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why won't you tell us what happened last night, sir?

speaker: SKINNER
line: Read the police report if you're really that curious.

speaker: MULDER
line: Does it explain why you refused to take a polygraph test? Or why there's a prostitute in the morgue with your fingerprints all over her?

speaker: SKINNER
line: You didn't know she was a prostitute, did you?

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: Walter. I just heard what happened. I was coming to see you.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: Walter?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you know him?

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: I used to think so. I'm Sharon Skinner. I'm his wife.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We were just a little caught off guard. Neither of us even knew that he was married. I mean, he never told us.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: Well, one of the things Walter has always been good at is keeping secrets. But the truth is, we haven't been together for almost 8 months.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Has he always been such a private person?

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: It's more than that. He lives under this misguided notion that silence is strength. He's built a wall to keep everyone out.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Including you?

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: Yeah, especially me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is that why you were separated?

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: I just realized one day that we were no longer married. We'd become roommates instead. We were paying the bills, taking out the garbage... and I couldn't live like that any more.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Excuse me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Scully.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: You were one of the few people that Walter ever mentioned from work.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: Not that he said much, but from the way he talked, I could tell he respected you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where?

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: That's probably why I feel that I can ask you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ask me what?

speaker: SCULLY
line: OK.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: If Walter really killed that woman.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sorry. Mulder, we've gotta go. You have our numbers if you need to reach us.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: You still haven't answered my question.

speaker: MULDER
line: No. I don't think he did it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's going on here?

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: Agents Mulder and Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's right.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: I'm Special Agent Bonnecaze. I've been called up from the Norfolk field office to coordinate this inquiry.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I don't know what you do down in Norfolk, but last time I checked, rifling through a man's office was considered an invasion of privacy.

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: Well, we're operating under guidelines specified by the Office of Professional Conduct, a protocol I understand you've opted to disregard.

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you mean?

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: I want both of you to make yourselves available tomorrow afternoon.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Available for what?

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: A formal hearing regarding A.D. Skinner's case.

speaker: MULDER
line: What case? He hasn't even been charged yet.

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: The hearing is to assess and determine his ability to continue in his position as Assistant Director. In the meantime, we'll be appointing our own investigators to pursue any criminal case. And I must ask you to stop looking into this any further.

speaker: MULDER
line: For what? In case we might turn up any evidence that might support his innocence?

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: Any evidence you may have obtained, Agent Mulder, you'll be presenting tomorrow afternoon at the hearing.

speaker: MULDER
line: Skinner's not answering his phone.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He's doing everything he shouldn't be doing.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. Why? He knows better than that. The evidence is still circumstantial at best.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He's behaving like a guilty man, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: The man's marriage is breaking up. He's stressed out, you know, he's...

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's his irrational behavior that concerns me. It speaks to a state of mind. If, if a, if an otherwise stable man is compelled to go out and hire a prostitute, what else is he capable of?

speaker: MULDER
line: Please. Give him the benefit of the doubt.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I *am*, Mulder, believe me. I'm not trying to convince myself.

speaker: MULDER
line: When I mentioned that hooker to him, he didn't even seem to know.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, maybe he doesn't remember.

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you mean? Either he remembers or he's a liar.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Not necessarily.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This man is running away from a train. He sees it coming straight at him. He hears its whistle. Several times a month, he ran away from that train. Until one night, he broke his wife's arm when he threw her to the floor.

speaker: MULDER
line: Night terrors?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, night terrors and sleep walking occur doing slow-wave non-dream sleep. The clinical term for this is REM sleep behavior disorder. Although rare, dozens of cases of sleep-related violence have been attributed to it.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's fascinating, but what does it have to do with Skinner?

speaker: SCULLY
line: This video tape came from the Bethesda Sleep Disorder Center, where Skinner has been receiving treatment for the past three months.

speaker: MULDER
line: For running away from trains?

speaker: SCULLY
line: The same disorder, different dreams. According to Skinner's psychiatrist, he's been experiencing a recurring dream in which he's confronted by an old woman. She speaks to him but he doesn't understand the words. Sometimes, she, she straddles his chest, suffocating him.

speaker: MULDER
line: So you think that Skinner may have killed the victim in his sleep?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Defending himself against this imaginary old woman. A lot of these patients have no recollection of their nocturnal activities, which might explain Skinner's amnesia.

speaker: MULDER
line: And it's not such a strange story.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It isn't?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's ancient, actually. You may have heard it, although not in such clinical terms. In the middle ages, a visitation like the one Skinner described would have been attributed to a succubus. It's a spirit that visits men in the night, usually in the form of an old woman.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Visits them for sex?

speaker: MULDER
line: Usually. Though sometimes the succubus becomes so attached to the man that she would kill any woman competing for his affection. Here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's that?

speaker: MULDER
line: Reports of residual luminous phenomena have been associated with some succubus encounters, at least according to the mythology. Why?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I feel kinda strange saying this, but I found something during my post-mortem exam that I think you should see.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's a circular patch around the victim's mouth and nose, approximately 11 centimeters in diameter. It retained light energy. It glowed in the dark.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I know what I saw, Mulder. It was here.

speaker: MULDER
line: This phosphorescence required no UV or infrared light?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. It was definitely visible to the naked eye.

speaker: MULDER
line: Did you get a sample?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. I sent on over to Chem-Tox.

speaker: MULDER
line: And?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, my first hunch was that it was some kind of a fungal growth, but the only substance that they detected was amylase, which is found in saliva. So I had them send a sample to the elemental analysis unit. The results should be back. Yes, this is Agent Dana Scully. I'm calling to find out the lab results on a tissue sample that I sent in earlier this morning. Thank you.

speaker: MULDER
line: What'd they say?

speaker: SCULLY
line: That there was no analyzable substance in the sample container.

speaker: MULDER
line: Are you sure you saw something?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I'm afraid this isn't exactly something that I'd make up.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe that's it. Maybe that's why Skinner's running. He's afraid.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That he did it?

speaker: MULDER
line: That he doesn't know he didn't do it.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: Hi. You didn't answer your phone. It just kept ringing.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Yeah, I unplugged it. I haven't been sleeping too well lately.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: So, are you going to invite me in, or should I start building an ark?

speaker: SKINNER
line: Come in.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: You still haven't gotten around to unpacking.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Yeah, well, you know... work. So what are you doing here, Sharon?

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: I'm not sure. After I saw you today, I didn't know what else to do.

speaker: SKINNER
line: If you're trying to satisfy some morbid curiousity about what happened...

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: That's not why I came. I just... I just want to make sure you're OK.

speaker: SKINNER
line: I'm OK. Except right now, company's about the last thing that I need.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: I'm not company. I'm your wife.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Ex-wife. Remember, you're the one who asked for the divorce.

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: Only because you didn't have the guts to ask for one yourself. So don't put it on me.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Fair enough. So what else do you want me to say?

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: Nothing. I don't want you to say anything. I just want you to let me in. Just this one time.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Why?

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: Because I know you. I know that you're scared and that you could use some comfort. I also know that you'll never let me give it to you. Take care of yourself, OK?

speaker: SKINNER
line: What's this about?

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: Come on, grab your coat and come with us. We'd like to ask you a few questions.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Why? What the hell is going on here?

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: It's your wife. She's been in an accident.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Is she all right?

speaker: DETECTIVE WALTOS
line: Someone ran her off the road. You're gonna have to come with us. We'll also need to see the keys to your car, sir.

speaker: SECOND DISTRICT POLICE STATION, 7
line: 44 AM

speaker: SKINNER
line: How is she?

speaker: MULDER
line: The C.T. scan showed a subdural hematoma. She's in surgery right now to relieve pressure on her brain. Scully's trying to get more information.

speaker: SKINNER
line: I have to see her.

speaker: MULDER
line: You can't do that, sir.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Why not? They said I wasn't being charged.

speaker: MULDER
line: Not yet. But they're building a pretty convincing case.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Do you think I did this to Sharon?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, I don't, but I'm in the minority.

speaker: SKINNER
line: What about Agent Scully?

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully... Scully doesn't understand why you're not trying to defend yourself.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Defend myself against what? Don't you think if I knew what was happening to me that I would try to... I don't know what to believe any more.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about the old woman in your dream. Who is she? It's gonna come out. Look, if you don't start trusting someone, you don't stand a chance.

speaker: SKINNER
line: A few months ago, I started seeing her again.

speaker: MULDER
line: Again?

speaker: SKINNER
line: I told you once what... what happened to me in Vietnam. I was caught in an ambush.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, you were the sole survivor. You also described what sounded like a near-death experience.

speaker: SKINNER
line: There was nothing "near" about it, Agent Mulder. I was a dead man.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's when you first saw her?

speaker: SKINNER
line: I saw lots of things over there. I didn't give much credence to any of them.

speaker: MULDER
line: And why not?

speaker: SKINNER
line: I got through that experience like most eighteen-year-olds... by numbing myself with whatever was around. I was no choirboy, I... I inhaled.

speaker: MULDER
line: So you just dismissed her as another hallucination?

speaker: SKINNER
line: I tried.

speaker: MULDER
line: But you couldn't?

speaker: SKINNER
line: She was there with me. Watching me as I was watching myself dying, my blood spilling from a hundred different places. Until she lifted me up and carried me back... away from the light.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, maybe she was trying to protect you. Maybe she's trying to protect you now.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Protect me from what?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's a question only you can answer.

speaker: SKINNER
line: I don't know. I don't have a clue.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Number 5.

speaker: MULDER
line: This is Skinner's car?

speaker: SCULLY
line: According to Woltos' report, the hood was still warm when they got to Skinner's apartment, even with the rain. Look at the left front panel. The matched the paint in the dent to Sharon Skinner's car.

speaker: MULDER
line: Woltos' people finish going over the interior?

speaker: SCULLY
line: The only prints they found on the steering wheel were Skinner's.

speaker: MULDER
line: Can I borrow your flashlight?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sure. Why?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't know what you're expecting to find, Mulder, but uh, Skinner's hearing is in half an hour.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'll meet you there.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you doing?

speaker: MULDER
line: Collecting evidence.

speaker: AGENT PENDRELL
line: You know how an airbag works?

speaker: MULDER
line: Your car hits something, a bag fills with air and you don't die.

speaker: AGENT PENDRELL
line: Not air. Nitrogen. Now, the latent image - the one we're interested in - is found in the byproduct of that explosion, in the finely dispersed sodium metal that coats the interior of the airbag. See this powder, here? It's created by whoever was behind the wheel when the airbag deployed.

speaker: MULDER
line: It doesn't look like a face.

speaker: AGENT PENDRELL
line: Not yet. First, I'm scanning the fabric. Then I'm running it through software which translates its varying densities into a dimensionalized likeness. After that, it's a matter of fine tuning.

speaker: MULDER
line: How long does that fine-tuning take?

speaker: AGENT PENDRELL
line: You need this in a hurry, it sounds like.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not the only one who needs it.

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: We're still waiting for Agent Mulder?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes, sir.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: We're finished waiting. We're going to begin without him. Have a seat.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: Let's go over the physical evidence again. You say you found nothing damning.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, sir. None of the physical evidence we recovered directly connects the assistant director to her death.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: You re-examined the victim's body. Did you find anything of note?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I took a sample of an extraneous substance that turned out to be unidentifiable.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: How's that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: A naturally occurring enzyme around her mouth and nose.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: And do you have any idea why it was there?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: If you are withholding something from this committee...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sir, I feel reluctant to say or to speak for Agent Mulder.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: To say what?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Agent Mulder had a theory that the substance could have come from a visitation.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: But you have another explanation?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. I'm sorry, I don't.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: Do you believe in paranormal phenomena, Agent Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Whatever extreme cases I have encountered I have always viewed through the lens of science. I believe that is why I was assigned to the X-Files and to Agent Mulder.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: And has A.D. Skinner always been as discriminating as you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Excuse me, sir, I don't understand the question.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: Would you say that, like yourself, your direct superior has been affected by, or enchanted by, Agent Mulder's notions...

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, sir. Not at all.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: And yet, he continues to sign off on whatever extreme cases you and Agent Mulder elect to investigate.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I believe the Assistant Director has protected us out of a respect for the work.

speaker: SENIOR AGENT
line: Just as you might protect him? By trumping up unidentifiable evidence?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. That is not true.

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: Thank you, Agent Scully, that will be all.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sir, if I may...

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: That will be all.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm not finished.

speaker: AGENT BONNECAZE
line: Yes, you are, Agent Scully.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hello.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Hello.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You missed it. Not that anything you said would have made a difference.

speaker: MULDER
line: What happened, where's Skinner?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Out of a job.

speaker: MULDER
line: They dismissed him?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He would have had a better chance against a firing squad.

speaker: MULDER
line: And they used us to do it, didn't they? They used the X-Files.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How'd you know?

speaker: MULDER
line: Because I think Skinner's been out-maneuvered, Scully. They found a weakness and they're exploiting it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But why?

speaker: MULDER
line: To put us in check. You remove Skinner and you weaken us.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What am I looking at?

speaker: MULDER
line: This is the man that stole Skinner's car last night and tried to kill his wife.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't understand. Why would they orchestrate such an elaborate scheme just to set him up? Why not just kill him?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, they already tried that once, and a second attempt would be too obvious, even for these thugs. Anyway, I think Skinner's probably worth more to them alive in disgrace than dead and buried.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who is this guy?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know. Danny couldn't find anything on him. He's still running it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So how are we supposed to find him?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, this guy's a pawn. Pawns always make the first move.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So he must have hired the prostitute.

speaker: MULDER
line: What happened here?

speaker: POLICEMAN
line: Jumper. It happens whenever it rains two days straight.

speaker: MULDER
line: He got to her first.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, look.

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: Usually, there'd be something set up in the room. To get pictures, tape, whatever.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Judy, we need you to identify somebody.

speaker: MULDER
line: Is this the man who hired Carina?

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: He said that nobody would get hurt.

speaker: MULDER
line: He lied. Skinner's not the only person he set up.

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: Are you saying he killed Carina?

speaker: SCULLY
line: And Lorraine. He's cleaning house.

speaker: MULDER
line: I need you to arrange a meeting.

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: Wha? I can't. I mean, Lorraine's the only one who ever really talked to him.

speaker: MULDER
line: Unfortunately, Lorraine can't get to the phone right now.

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: Please don't make me do this.

speaker: MULDER
line: Look what he did to your friends. We're your only chance of coming out of this OK.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Agent Mulder's right. I'll stay with you if you want, until we take him into custody.

speaker: MULDER
line: I want you to call him. Tell him you're scared because we questioned you. Tell him you want money to get out of town. You'll meet him at the Ambassodor Hotel bar. OK?

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: Hello. Hi. This is Judy Fairly. You might not remember me, but I work for Lorraine.

speaker: MAN
line: One moment, please.

speaker: GRAY-HAIRED MAN
line: Yes?

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: Some FBI agents came to see me about what happened to Lorraine.

speaker: GRAY-HAIRED MAN
line: What did you tell them?

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: Nothing. I didn't say anything. But they scared the hell out of me. Look. I need some money.

speaker: GRAY-HAIRED MAN
line: That can be arranged.

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: Can you meet me?

speaker: GRAY-HAIRED MAN
line: Where would you like to meet?

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: The Ambassador Hotel at... in an hour.

speaker: GRAY-HAIRED MAN
line: I'm close. I'll see you in an hour.

speaker: SKINNER
line: I had to tell you, Sharon, before anything else happens. I'm not signing those papers... for a lot of reasons, most of them I'm just realizing myself for the first time. Some of the things I've seen - the violence and the lies that I've witnessed men inflict on one another - I could never tell you that. Not that I ever stopped believing in the work, but there were contradictions that I, that I couldn't reconcile, which meant shutting down part of myself just to do my job. I never told you what I should have told you... that what really got me through each day was knowing that I'd be sleeping next to you that night. Knowing that I had a reason to wake up in the morning. I'm not sure if you can even hear me now, or if it even makes a difference to you any more, but I at least wanted you to know that.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Sharon?

speaker: SKINNER
line: Somebody...

speaker: SHARON SKINNER
line: Listen to me...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Did you get him?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, he hasn't shown up yet.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He should have been here fifteen minutes ago.

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: What's going on?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Nothing.

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: Great.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe it's the rain.

speaker: MULDER
line: This guy isn't about to let a little rain stop him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, hang on a second. Judy?

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, what's going on?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, get up here right now.

speaker: MULDER
line: He's upstairs.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Judy?

speaker: JUDY FAIRLY
line: What the hell are you doing?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm sorry. I called but you didn't answer.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's the matter?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Uhhh...

speaker: MULDER
line: You OK?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mmm-hmmm...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sir?

speaker: SKINNER
line: Come in.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is our report. You'll see, though, that several questions remain unanswered.

speaker: SKINNER
line: The identity of the man I shot?

speaker: SCULLY
line: We ran his face and fingerprints through every available database. There's still no matches. And we're doing a dental record search, but that'll probably be a dead end, too. And regarding the other man... the telephone number that we had for him has been disconnected, and there's no record of an account.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Don't waste your time, Agent Scully. You won't find him. Just get whatever forensic evidence you need off the body you have and bury it.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Is there a problem, Agent Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, there's something else you'll find missing in there. An explanation for how you knew to be at the hotel last night. I was hoping you could fill in that line item yourself.

speaker: SKINNER
line: I'm afraid I can't do that, at least not at this point in time.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why not?

speaker: SKINNER
line: Because whatever I believe may have happened... it has no place on an official report.

speaker: MULDER
line: Then why don't you tell me? Off the record.

speaker: SKINNER
line: If you'll excuse me, I've got some catching up to do. The O.P.C. did a number on my office. But I want to thank you for the quick turnaround on this.
